words.meaning: Showy but cheap and of poor quality.
examples: She wore a tawdry dress that looked like it came from a costume shop.
The hotel lobby was decorated with tawdry furniture and imitation art.

words.meaning: Physically or mentally demanding.
examples: Climbing the mountain was a taxing experience.
The new job proved to be more taxing than she had expected.

words.meaning: Relating to the branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms; systematic.
examples: The botanist organized the plants according to their taxonomic relationships.
A new taxonomic system was proposed for the recently discovered species.

words.meaning: The branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms; systematics.
examples: The taxonomy of insects is a complex and ever-evolving field.
He is an expert in the taxonomy of marine mammals.

words.meaning: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry.
examples: Modern technology has revolutionized the way we communicate.
The company invests heavily in new technology to stay competitive.

words.meaning: Too long, slow, or dull: tiresome or monotonous.
examples: The long, tedious meeting seemed to have no end.
He found the work of data entry to be extremely tedious.

words.meaning: Having a striking or revealing effect; significant.
examples: His silence was a telling response to her question.
The most telling detail was the look of fear in his eyes.

words.meaning: Revealing, indicating, or betraying something.
examples: The telltale smell of smoke alerted them to the fire.
The mud on his shoes was a telltale sign that he had been outside.

words.meaning: Excessive confidence or boldness; audacity.
examples: He had the temerity to ask for a raise after only a week on the job.
No one had the temerity to question the dictator's authority.

words.meaning: A person's nature, especially as it permanently affects their behavior.
examples: He has a fiery temper and is easily angered.
The blacksmith will temper the steel to make it stronger.

words.meaning: Abstinence from alcoholic drink.
examples: The temperance movement sought to ban the sale of alcohol.
He practiced temperance in all things, including his diet.

words.meaning: Relating to or denoting a region or climate characterized by mild temperatures.
examples: The temperate climate is ideal for growing a variety of crops.
She has a temperate personality and is not prone to emotional outbursts.

words.meaning: Having a specified character or disposition.
examples: The steel was tempered to increase its strength.
His optimism was tempered by a dose of realism.

words.meaning: Characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion.
examples: They had a tempestuous relationship, marked by frequent arguments.
The tempestuous sea crashed against the shore.

words.meaning: Relating to worldly as opposed to spiritual affairs; secular.
examples: The king was concerned with temporal matters, such as politics and war.
The temporal lobes of the brain are involved in memory and emotion.

words.meaning: Able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
examples: His argument was not tenable and was easily refuted.
The ceasefire agreement proved not to be tenable.

words.meaning: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
examples: The tenacious reporter would not give up until she had the full story.
He had a tenacious grip on her arm.

words.meaning: The quality or fact of being able to grip something firmly; grip.
examples: She admired the tenacity of the small plant growing through a crack in the pavement.
With sheer tenacity, he managed to complete the marathon.

words.meaning: Expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one.
examples: The newspaper article was a tendentious piece of propaganda.
He gave a tendentious and biased account of the events.

words.meaning: To offer or present (something) formally.
examples: He tendered his resignation to the board of directors.
The company will tender a bid for the construction contract.

words.meaning: A principle or belief, especially one of the main principles of a religion or philosophy.
examples: One of the basic tenets of democracy is freedom of speech.
He lived his life according to a strict set of moral tenets.

words.meaning: Relating to tension; capable of being drawn out or stretched.
examples: The tensile strength of the rope was tested to ensure its safety.
Steel has high tensile strength, making it ideal for construction.

words.meaning: Not certain or fixed; provisional.
examples: We made tentative plans to meet for lunch next week.
He took a few tentative steps into the dark room.

words.meaning: Very weak or slight.
examples: He had a tenuous grasp of the complex scientific theory.
The link between the two events was tenuous and difficult to prove.

words.meaning: (especially of a liquid) only slightly warm; lukewarm.
examples: The coffee was tepid and unappetizing.
The play received a tepid response from the critics.

words.meaning: To bring to an end.
examples: The company decided to terminate his contract.
The train will terminate at the next station.

words.meaning: Dry land; the ground as distinct from the sea or air.
examples: After weeks at sea, the sailors were glad to be back on terra firma.
He felt much safer on terra firma than he did in the rickety airplane.

words.meaning: Of, on, or relating to the earth.
examples: Lions are terrestrial animals, while dolphins are marine animals.
The spacecraft searched for signs of terrestrial life on other planets.

words.meaning: Sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
examples: He gave a terse and to-the-point reply.
Her terse response indicated that she was not in the mood for conversation.

words.meaning: Bad-tempered and irritable.
examples: He was a tetchy old man who was always complaining.
She was feeling tetchy after a long and stressful day.

words.meaning: A conclusive test of the success or value of something.
examples: The final exam will be the acid test of his knowledge.
The new product's performance in the market will be the acid test of its design.

words.meaning: An event has happened or a decision has been made that cannot be changed.
examples: Once he submitted his resignation, the die was cast.
She knew that once she stepped on the plane, the die would be cast and her old life would be over.

words.meaning: The female side of a family.
examples: The inheritance passed down through the distaff side of the family.
She inherited her artistic talent from the distaff side.

words.meaning: The circulation of rumors and unofficial information.
examples: I heard on the grapevine that she's getting married.
News travels fast on the office grapevine.

words.meaning: The largest part of something.
examples: The oldest son received the lion's share of the inheritance.
The CEO took the lion's share of the credit for the company's success.

words.meaning: The gist or main point of a matter.
examples: The sum and substance of his argument was that the plan was too risky.
In sum and substance, the new policy will have little effect on most people.

words.meaning: A constantly threatening danger.
examples: The threat of nuclear war hung like a sword of Damocles over the world.
Living with a chronic illness can feel like having a sword of Damocles hanging over you.

words.word: the world, the flesh, and the devil
words.meaning: All forms of temptation to which humankind is subject.
examples: The preacher warned his congregation against the temptations of the world, the flesh, and the devil.
He struggled to resist the allure of the world, the flesh, and the devil.

words.meaning: A clear sign of impending disaster.
examples: When the company started laying off workers, the writing was on the wall.
She saw the writing on the wall and left her job before she was fired.

words.meaning: A system of government in which priests rule in the name of God or a god.
examples: Ancient Egypt was a theocracy, with the pharaoh considered a living god.
The country is a modern theocracy, ruled by religious leaders.

words.meaning: Treatment intended to relieve or heal a disorder.
examples: She is undergoing therapy for her depression.
Physical therapy helped him recover from his injury.

words.meaning: Relating to drama and the theater; an actor or actress.
examples: He is a talented thespian who has starred in many plays.
The local theater group is looking for aspiring thespians.

words.meaning: Complete with regard to every detail; not superficial or partial.
examples: The police conducted a thorough investigation of the crime.
She has a thorough understanding of the subject.

words.meaning: Involving or attending to every detail or aspect of something; thorough.
examples: The new government has promised a thoroughgoing reform of the tax system.
He is a thoroughgoing professional who always does his best work.

words.meaning: Using money and other resources carefully and not wastefully.
examples: She is a thrifty shopper who always looks for bargains.
He was taught to be thrifty and to save his money.

words.meaning: A large, densely packed crowd of people or animals.
examples: A throng of fans gathered to see the celebrity.
The narrow streets were thronged with tourists.

words.meaning: Under all circumstances, no matter how difficult.
examples: They have been friends for years and have stuck together through thick and thin.
She promised to support him through thick and thin.

words.meaning: An indication of rejection, disapproval, or failure.
examples: The boss gave a thumbs down to his proposal.
The new movie got a thumbs down from the critics.

words.meaning: To prevent (someone) from accomplishing something.
examples: The police thwarted the robbers' attempt to rob the bank.
Her plans for a surprise party were thwarted when he found out about it.

words.meaning: The character or quality of a musical sound or voice as distinct from its pitch and intensity.
examples: She has a beautiful voice with a rich, warm timbre.
The timbre of the cello is deeper than that of the violin.

words.meaning: Done or occurring at a favorable or useful time; opportune.
examples: The timely arrival of the ambulance saved his life.
She gave a timely and relevant presentation.

words.meaning: Showing or suffering from nervousness, fear, or a lack of confidence.
examples: The timorous little mouse scurried away from the cat.
He had a timorous and hesitant manner.

words.meaning: To color slightly.
examples: The sunset tinged the clouds with pink and gold.
Her voice had a tinge of sadness.

words.meaning: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
examples: He launched into a tirade against the government.
She was subjected to a long tirade from her angry boss.

words.meaning: Holding or constituting a purely formal position or title without any real authority.
examples: The queen is the titular head of the Church of England.
He was the titular head of the company, but his son made all the important decisions.

words.meaning: (especially of a criminal or dangerous animal) at liberty; escaped or not yet captured.
examples: The escaped prisoner is still at large.
The dangerous dog is at large in the neighborhood.

words.meaning: To be in good health or spirits.
examples: He was in fine fettle after his vacation.
She was in fine fettle and ready to take on any challenge.

words.meaning: To be in disgrace or under suspicion.
examples: He has been under a cloud ever since the scandal.
The company is under a cloud of suspicion for its accounting practices.

words.meaning: To confront a powerful or dangerous person on their own ground.
examples: The young journalist decided to beard the lion in his den and confront the corrupt politician directly.
It takes a lot of courage to beard the lion.

words.meaning: To do or say something to relieve tension or get conversation going in a strained situation or when strangers meet.
examples: He told a joke to break the ice and get everyone to relax.
A good way to break the ice at a party is to ask people about themselves.
